The restriction is partially due to the fact that the TEI uses the same elements of the abstract model to serve many kinds of text-modelling tasks, and standardly employs ‘features’ or ‘facets’ of these elements (known in the XML world as attributes) to express differences among them. The structural context of these elements often matters as well. The fact that some elements of the serialization have names closely corresponding to what we can customarily find in the dictionary model is more or less a lucky coincidence. It is not the pattern to be expected. A lexicographer coming from outside of the TEI should not, therefore, expect her customary terms (names of dictionary objects in the dictionary model) to be straightforwardly reflected in the TEI vocabulary names.

A good introductory-level illustration is provided by the elements form and sense, which might be expected to contain information about form (of the headword and related items) and about the sense, respectively. And they do, except they do it in several ways:

In some cases, the differences in the interpretation of elements such as form make it necessary to adopt a rule that they never appear without an accompanying @type attribute (so the above example is incomplete from the point of view of TEI-Lex0; see also the section on spoken and written forms below).

Another good example for the necessity of realising and bearing in mind the discrepancy between the TEI element names and the names of dictionary object in a dictionary model is the element cit. Originally, its TEI name came from the word “citation” and this is what the element was used for up to the early days of TEI P5, when it acquired a new, broader function of grouping together a piece of text perceived or broadly treated as “foreign” or additional, together with its description (in bibliographic, linguistic, usage-oriented sense). At this point, the element became a common “box” for citations, dictionary examples and also translation equivalents, and the interpretation of the element name “cit” became so broad that it cannot be used without extra information provided by its @type attribute (the TEI Guidelines tacitly assume that a @type-less cit can be used for citations, but in TEI-Lex0, we enforce the use of the @type attribute throughout). div.head: Unified representation of entries
div.p: In the current guidelines, the TEI defines four different container elements that may serve as grouping devices for lexical information on the level of entries (the following definitions are taken from the TEI guidelines, emphasis added):

list.item: entry: contains a single structured entry in any kind of lexical resource, such as a dictionary or lexicon.
entryFree: contains a single unstructured entry in any kind of lexical resource, such as a dictionary or lexicon.
superEntry: groups a sequence of entries within any kind of lexical resource, such as a dictionary or lexicon which function as a single unit, for example a set of homographs.
re: (related entry) contains a dictionary entry for a lexical item related to the headword, such as a compound phrase or derived form, embedded inside a larger entry.

div.p: These four elements can be used to distinguish types of entries along two conceptual axes:

list.item: Containing vs. contained entries: entries may contain lexical information that can be conceived as a dictionary entry in its own right, possibly alongside additional form related or other lexical information. Specifically, superEntry may contain entry and entry in turn may contain re to represent the embedding of lexical entries on three distinct levels. Due to re being allowed to be used recursively, the number of levels for representing entry-like lexical information inside other such blocks is effectively unrestricted.

Structured vs. unstructured entries,This situation is somewhat comparable to <div1>, <div2> etc. vs. recursive div. Maybe this analogy should be mentioned explicitly in the text?I don't think the analogy holds in this case: divN vs. recursive div is not a matter of structure vs. lack of it, but rather of different views on expressing the serialization of an assumed model (whether you assign some kind of additional categorizational value to the numbered div vs. concentrating on typing divs and possibly on counting or otherwise detecting their nesting levels).Besides, we probably don't want to alert those in the TEI community to whom the numbered-div vs. recursive-div distinction is an issue comparable to a blood feud ;-) i. e. entries that can readily be represented (in the lexical view) in the spirit of the TEI guideline’s dictionary chapter (entry, re) vs. entries that for some reason violate the generic content model of entry or re and thus have to be represented more freely (<entryFree). A third category in this respect are entries that exhibit a highly reduced amount of lexical content while this content is still of essentially entry-like nature (superEntry).

div.p: In TEI-Lex-0, we refrain from this unnecessary and complex cross-classification of entries with regard to their place within an entry hierarchy (first axis above) and the rigidity of the lexical structuring they exhibit (second axis above). Instead of using four different elements for entry-like objects, only entry is used. In order to still be able to construct hierarchies of embedded entries, entry will need to be allowed to occur recursively (e. g. by making it part of model.entrypart.top). However, this leads to a non conservative deviation from the TEI guidelines.

div.head: Types of entries
div.p: Based on the proposed definition for entry in TEI-Lex-0, entries are conceived as “the most basic” elements of the microstructure. The examples provided in the section Unified representation of entries illustrate two applications of entries embedded within entries and make it obvious that different types of linguistic entities can be represented by entry in one single dictionary. Therefore, the provision of a @type attribute for entry is encouraged in such cases. The value for the type attribute shall denote a property of the entry as a whole that is not represented more specifically by way of other elements within the entry. It is for example not good practice to use e. g. the part-of-speech as the value for entry/@type because this information is encoded in gramGrp/pos.
The current TEI guidelines suggest the set of the following values for @type:

list.item: abbr
affix
foreign
hom
main
sub
supplemental
xref

div.p: Again, the list of values represent features from a considerable range of axes. Moreover, the features are not mutually exclusive (e. g. a foreign abbreviation may well be a homonym). The values belong to different domains: morphology (abbr), etymology (foreign), orthography and possibly phonology (hom), and (in a broad sense) the macrostructure of the dictionary (main, supplemental, xr). Of these domains, all except the dictionary’s macrostructure are catered for in specific elements below the level of the entry. They should therefore not be used as types of entries.

In general, the entry type can be applied locally for a single dictionary or globally to allow for classification across different dictionaries. Provided that a single dictionary will often comprise entries that describe linguistic entities of the same kind (“words”, word families, multi-word expressions, morphemes, …) a classification along those lines will be of minor importance for a stand-alone resource but may be useful in a multi-dictionary use-case. Possible values for this domain include:

list.item: affix
word
synsete.g. for onomasiological dictionaries… though this is not the primary concern of the TEI it reads elsewhere in this text. (Laurent?)
multi-word-entity
word-family

div.p: A classification based on macrostructural properties (i. e. properties describing aspects of the internal organisation of a resource) can on the other hand be exploited both for a single dictionary and across different dictionaries. Possible values for this domain include:

list.item: main
supplemental
nest
niche
xr

div.head: Towards a more systematic use of sense
Guidelines
div.p: In the current TEI dictionary chapter, the content model of entry allows one to have sense-related information directly within entry. The present guidelines recommend a stricter use of these elements so that sense-related information is better localised within the sense element, in accordance with the underlying semasiological model implemented in the TEI Guidelines.

sense is thus made mandatory for any dictionary entry that actually provides sense information for the headword. Further in this document, we consider some additional specific cases (e.g. “referencing” entries, or inflexional lexica At INT, we make a distinction between a dictionary and a computational lexicon. These also commonly don't have sense information.where the entry is limited to the provision of inflected forms), where sense is not a mandatory child of entry.

As a consequence of making the use of sense more systematic within entry, we have seen (see section on entry) that some elements are no longer allowed as children of entry. We provide here a specific background for each of them:

list.item: def is clearly intended to provide a prose description of a meaning within a sense element and should not appear in any other context;

div.head: A limited number of possible contexts for def
div.p: In the current TEI guidelines, def is allowed to be used within the following elements:

list.item: Module core: cit
Module dictionaries: dictScrap, entry, entryFree, etym, hom, re, sense

div.p: Apart from the case of nym (cf. note below), the present recommendations limit the use of def to sense, cit and etym. All other existing contexts would be implemented by embedding def within a sense.

Note: nym currently has a very sloppy content model taking up many elements from the dictionary chapter without eliciting clear encoding recommendations on their usage. In particular, examples associated to nym offer a very loose usage of such elements (e.g. using form without an orth element), which are even more in contradiction with the recommendation made in the present document. div.head: Deprecating hom
div.p: Making a clear difference between a situation where an entry has to be split into two or more homonyms and one where these differences correspond to a semantic alternation is lexicographically difficult.Yes. This has been reiterated in the lexicographic and lexicological literature as the eternally debated split between polysemy and homonymy. Given the history of this issue and the heaps of paper devoted to it, I do _not_ think that glossing over this problem will do us any good. Specifically, the current recommendation is to ignore this issue altogether -- I don't see any mechanism that allows those who need this distinction to maintain it. This is not good, we're cutting away part of the target community in this way.I can't think of a coherent positive part to the present remark at this moment, unfortunately: I am afraid that `@type` is of no help in such cases. I could imagine a join element indicating groupings, e.g. groupings of senses into polysemous wholes (hmm, that could actually be worth a moment of discussion in Budapest, because of how versatile such a solution can be).Thinking on this further: we could suggest a rule, whereby, _if_ someone needs to maintain a distinction between homonymy and polysemy in their dictionary, they use separate entry elements for the former, and the sense mechanism within a single entry for the latter. The drawback of this solution is that it imposes a structure in a content-driven setting (because our starting point is digitization of legacy dictionaries, unless I'm confused). So it may happen that the legacy dictionary keeps homonyms within a single entry, and then the above solution would fail.True Still, the main danger in keeping both possibilities in the representation of a lexical entry in a digital lexicon is to introduce a systematic structural ambiguity as to where the appropriate information is to be found. defmake a cry or sound of this kind.</def>
should actually be represented as follows:

The current TEI formulation allows for an extremely wide range of encoding possibilities. Below, we suggest ways in which the elements, in particular form, can be constrained. We give examples of use types not covered by the Guidelines, and propose some extensions.

div.head: A note on inheritance
div.p: We assume that in order to determine the complete properties of an element inside the entry tree, the principle of default inheritance applies, e.g. grammatical properties of a form are determined by collecting the sibling gramGrp of the ancestor-or-self of the focus element, where the superordinate grammatical properties can be overwritten by the lower-level properties. This principle is relatively straightforward in the case of grammatical properties, but more complex for the word paradigm, esp. in cases of variant forms. For more information c.f. Ide et al. (2000) and Erjavec et al. (2000).

div.head: Grammatical properties of lexical entries
div.p: Grammatical properties of lexical entries should be specified in entry/gramGrp. This element will typically specify the part-of-speech of the entry.

list.item: Grammatical properties of the entry should not be specified in entry/form[@type=”lemma”]/gramGrp

In cases where headwords are discriminated only on the basis of their orthography (e.g. in English dictionaries which treat conversion pairs of nouns and verbs, such as run, as belonging in single entries), entry/gramGrp should not be used, because its role is taken over by the individual sense/gramGrp. div.head: Representation of the lemma
div.p: The form element should always be qualified by its type, where its values should be from the list of recommended (allowed?) values. The lemma (i.e. headword) form should be under form[@type=”lemma”].

If it is necessary to specify the grammatical properties of the lemma form itself (as opposed to the grammatical properties of the entry), this is described by entry/form[@type=”lemma”]/gramGrp, e.g.:

div.head: Representation of inflected forms
div.p: Dictionaries often include additional forms next to the lemma which are (in English) used to specify irregular forms, such as “corpus / corpora” or “take / took” and in inflectionally rich languages to enable the user to determine the correct paradigm of the word (such as “krava / -e” in Slovene).
Such inflected forms should be encoded in entry/form/@type=”inflected”, e.g.:

div.head: Paradigms
div.p: When several inflected forms can be present next to the lemma, these can be embedded into the entry/form[@type=”paradigm”] element. The decision on whether to use this extra element depends on the particular dictionary and language.

The other use case for paradigms is when the full inflectional paradigm of the word is embedded in the entry, i.e. when the dictionary also includes all the word-forms of the words covered, which can be useful for e.g. machine processing.

An entry may contain several paradigms, e.g. a partial one for humans and a full one for machines, or one for each stem of a verb. Each paradigm type should be distinguished by the form/@subtype attribute.

div.p: TEI already has in place the principle where specific elements can also be expressed as a general element refined by its @type, e.g. ab/@type=”p” ≡ p or seg/@type=”word” ≡ w. We propose to apply the same principle to form, as this would make the lexical entries more compact and readable for the lexicographers as well as enabling better validation.
In particular, the following new elements would be added, following the suggested values of form/@type with the some extensions:

list.item: lemma ≡ form/@type=”lemma”
inflected ≡ form/@type=”inflected”
phrase ≡ form/@type=”phrase”

div.head: Proposal: Using ref and xr to point to lexical entities
div.p: To unify lexical references, we propose to use ref as the general element for a lexical reference and to use xr as the enclosing element that groups information related to this reference. The reference may be internal to a dictionary or pointing to an external source, even when the actual target lexical object is not explicitly known. In the latter case, ref can be used without an explicit pointing attribute. Furthermore the actual intended target of the reference can be of various possible types, namely a full entry, but also a specific sense, form or morpheme within a given entry.
For all such usages, the following attributes may be used on xr and ref:

For frequency information provided explicitly (e.g. corpus frequencies), a separate element should be introduced.
